answers.text: to seek injunctions from possible protests

qas.question: Jealous and Radford asserted that the legal action taken by Shell was what?
Greenpeace claimed that Shell requested Google to ban what?

answers.text: video footage of a Greenpeace protest action that occurred at the Shell-sponsored Formula One (F1) Belgian Grand Prix

qas.question: What banners appeared on the winners' podium at the August 2013 ceremony?

answers.text: the use of four radio car antennas

qas.question: When did Shell ask google to ban video footage of the Greenpeace protests?

plausible_answers.text: half of a polar bear's head and half of the Shell logo

qas.question: Who filed the lawsuits against Shell?
Who did SaveTheArctic partner with for the Belgian Grand Prix?
How were the winners' podiums controlled?

context: In response, Shell filed lawsuits <a0_0>to seek injunctions from possible protests<a0_0/>, and <b7_0>Benjamin Jealous<b7_0/> of the NAACP and Radford argued that the legal action was <a1_0>"trampling American's rights."<a1_0/> According to Greenpeace, Shell lodged a request with Google to ban <a2_0>video footage of a Greenpeace protest action that occurred at the Shell-sponsored <b8_0>Formula One (F1)<b8_0/> Belgian Grand Prix<a2_0/> on <b5_0>25 August 2013<b5_0/>, in which <a3_0>"SaveTheArctic.org"<a3_0/> banners appear at the winners' podium ceremony. In the video, the banners rise up automatically—activists controlled their appearance with <a4_0>the use of <b9_0>four radio car antennas<b9_0/><a4_0/>—revealing the website URL, alongside an image that consists of <b6_0>half of a polar bear's head and half of the Shell logo<b6_0/>.
